Game mechanics: there is no crouching, instead there is Stringification, you can also apply you self to certain walls which act like ladders. It's 3rd person so you can see behind cover in certain situations. There is double jump and gliding. It may sound daunting but it's rather simple and easy mechanics.
Game requires decent aim, so mouse and keyboard. Gamepads are supported, it works well for melee/knife only mod.
Unlike Valorant or CS this one is more like Team Fortress where your agent is a class and comes with only 1 main weapon. You have sidearms: smg, deagle, shotgun and flamer and a sword, you can change your sidearm each round. You can't change your character main weapon, so if you pick a sniper you play a sniper for the whole half, on halftime you can change your character/class. Instead of buying weapons you buy upgrades for abilities armor and weapons. It is very simple and straightforward, I do feel some upgrades are better than some. There are utilities like nades, flash, healing nades etc. Character abilities are very simple and usually reveal an enemy, deal damage, or both, or they buff you and your team, or debuff enemy, depending on the character you play. There are 22 characters/agents in total.
The graphics are clean and easy to see, performance is good too.
UI is clean for the most part and it's easy to jump into the game.
There are bots or players who play like bots. I don't mind. If you think about it most games are like these nowadays.

This game revived my love for PVP games. 

After 10 years of grinding pointless rank numbers in multiple of games, getting several high ranks, just for them to go basically EOS (End of Service) with releasing skins and zero to no content making everything repetitive slog, and all my sweat and nerves wasted on those games become irrelevant (not like anyone would care in the first place), it's nice to play the game that actually puts effort in developing new content and gamemodes instead of pushing everyone in rank purgatory to burn their lives away. 

While there is a big problem of people being locked in bot lobbies for some reason, 
(which is strange, since i can only play demolition, escort and conquest with people, but any other mode is locked with bots. I thought that was a "play more matches so SBMM would know where to place you" type of thing, but i did play outbreak on release regularly against people, but after returning from a business trip one of the updates broke something and now i just can't get a non-bot lobby for outbreak even tho i know they exist, since people in my friend list are able to get in those matches. i'll update review if i find anything about it.) it is still fun enough of an experience because of how unique and expressive movement is in this game.

Also for anyone interested, you can easily detect bot lobbies by looking at their chips at the pre-lobby screen, since bots don't have any medals on them. 

Still, it does have a low playercount, which is undeniably true. I fear that global servers will go EOS and we won't be transferred to Chinese servers. 
But if you looking for an actually casual or unique PVP shooter with high skill celling and ability to queue into multiple gamemods at ones (which is a godsend), 
or a PVE game that pretends to be PVP if you into that kind of thing, 
then this game is for you.
Just keep in mind that servers ~miiiight~ go EOS sooner or later before buying lots of skins.

But to be honest - i don't care at this point. It's was a great ride, and if Strinova dies - i leave PVP games with it.
Thanks iDreamSky developer team for reviving my love for PVP games and skill expression, fly high you beautiful bastard.

Strinova struggles with frustrating matchmaking issues, where players frequently encounter mismatched players of vastly different skill levels. It is common to be paired in ranked games with opponents or teammates whose ranks vary widely, disrupting fair competition and the intended ranking system. This issue is worsened by a small player base, leading to long wait times and repeatedly facing the same mismatched players. Additionally, occasional lag spikes and network problems negatively affect gameplay. The monetization system leans towards pay-to-win, making progression and rewards challenging for free-to-play users. While the maps are well-designed and engaging, the presence of toxic players often disrupts the gaming experience, contributing further to player dissatisfaction. These persistent issues overshadow the game's innovative core mechanics and potential.

A really fun competitive game to play with friends.

The anime-style art surprisingly fits perfectly with the fast-paced competitive gameplay. What really sets this game apart is the Stringification mechanic. It allows you to flatten your character, stick to walls, slip into tight spaces, and even glide to dodge incoming attacks.

Overall, Strinova gives me a refreshing and unique experience. The combination of its art style and creative mechanics makes it stand out from other games in the genre.

Amazing gameplay, terrible monetization and advertising. 
     The gunplay and movement in this game is like no other, and while the stringification gimmick is funny looking at first, it's only once you start looking deeper that you realize its potential. The ability to dodge bullets and outplay your opponents with paper mode or, on the other side, shoot your opponents even when they're millimeters wide, means that the skill expression for this game is truly impressive. The characters might be somewhat generic, but are charming and the dorm system truly can make people fall in love with them (at least, the three that exist at the time of writing this post IDREAMSKY GIVE ME KOKONA DORM AND MY LIFE IS YOURS oh wait nvm i already sold my soul to the devil for bablos). The lore, while on hold by the devs, is surprisingly complex, with neither side being inherently good or bad, and with actual stakes behind it despite the nigh immortality this virtual world provides its residents (if i understand it correctly). 
     However, the monetization, as i alluded to before, is absolutely awful and combined with a number of other factors, killed the game on global (the chinese side is very popular tho, i've heard it hits 1 million concurrent users on weekends). Region lock severely limited player interaction and resulted in a lot of people leaving combined with the lackluster f2p rewards (smth like 200+ hrs to unlock all the characters according to some although I don't remember having anywhere near that trouble) and 100 usd only converting to 60 PULLS when you need 160 to guarantee all legendary gacha rewards (3 times that for the upcoming michele legendary btw, holy EA cosplay). The devs also chose to try and appeal to the casual audience, which I'm conflicted about. On one hand it only helped to grow the chinese scene and maybe held some global interest for a little bit. However, generally the people who stick around the longest, especially in a game with such competitive depth, are the competitive players, and IDS have been neglecting those players and the ranked system for about 3 seasons now. Rank inflation and bot lobbies, combined with the games horrible matchmaking system, means that mid and high elo feel absolutely awful to play, with either extremely high toxicity, clueless teammates, or both. 

I still highly recommend the game, as it is possibly the most fun and accessible competitive shooter I personally have ever played (if you don't believe me get past the bot lobbies and try the game out, then come back to flame me if you still believe). However, there are so many problems with the game OUTSIDE OF ITS CORE GAMEPLAY that I, even after playing the game since launch and with the amount of hours I have, cannot excuse.

Concept and theme is weird. The fact you can just turn yourself into paper sounds like a single character ability, but no, that's the entire game, so every character can do it.
It's fun and unique, but still, a weird idea.

The fact you can just stick to almost any wall and glide about anywhere makes movement really fun, and makes strategy and map perception interesting.

Monetization. They're not selling advantages. It's all skins. While the majority of the skins can be bought directly with money or their own currency, the real blingy flashy skins with unique animations and voice lines are behind a gacha system.
You can for the most part get enough currency to get the some of the skins, including legendary tier 1 skins after a while, but some  tier 2 skins are locked behind money, which are in rotations.

The game has basic shooting modes like elimination, demolition and escort, there is also something called Outbreak. Basically an infected mode where players are selected to be monsters, and infect others. They really lean into that lately.

Overall, I really like it.
Too bad about the player count. Matchmaking is rough.

In my opinion, this game is still a lot of fun, but there are moments where it genuinely feels like the matches are filled with bots. Iâ€™ll jump into a ranked game, end up with 30+ kills, and the next highest player will barely break six. It makes the whole experience feel unbalanced and takes away from the competitive side of the game.

Itâ€™s clear the player base has dropped off over time, which is disappointing because the core gameplay is actually enjoyable. I still find myself coming back to it, but I really hope the developers start focusing on polishing the mechanics, improving matchmaking, and giving long-term players reasons to stay. Constantly adding new skins each update is fine, but it shouldnâ€™t come at the cost of meaningful updates that enhance the game itself. A little more care and effort could really bring the community back to life.

Making this a PvE game and not an esport PvP game, which has been crowded for a long time; you have so much competition, like Valorant and Marvel Rivals. Following games like L4D2 and TF2, this game will last longer. If the service will go on making and making agents like Valorant, that is not content. Playing with beautiful characters is good. But a new male character needs a practical job, not just a character with different dress and clothing; it needs a story. It doesn't even help the parasocial visual novel of the game. If I want to play a visual novel game, then I'd rather play that. But in terms of design, the factions are kind of left over with no actual threat. It's like fighting paintball. The game will work more if it is a survival team game, and MOBA is an alternative. You can actually use the mutant models and robot. I want the game to be alive but not the way you see it. Make it a rogue-like team-based game, and it will have use of the lore. Not the Genshin-style switching; just L4D2â€”you choose a character, then you can play Horde of Evacuation in the map.

negative.review:
Played it from release until the start of season 3 when I stopped, so here's my thoughts.

Good:
-paper mechanic, although looks goofy, it actually feels fresh and even good as you learn to use it for movement
-gameplay is actually really smooth which I didnt expect from an anime looking game that I never heard about before (I found it on the daily steam discovery queue)
-fun with friends, like any multiplayer ig
-gameplay actually has depth and you can do a lot of things that will help you improve, other than just having good aim

Bad:
-low playerbase which results in many other issues like long waiting time for matchmaking and unbalanced matchmaking and such, making players in ranked be sick and tired and more likely to be toxic, or they stop playing ranked and they flood the casual matches, so you cant even catch a break even if you are trying to play something casual and relax
-unbalanced characters. even at base, some characters are always better than others, but when you take into account map control and specific strategies and synergies, the right character makes a difference of heaven or hell 
-monetization is really bad, getting 1 legendary skin is way too expensive, and even then you can end up getting the weapon skin instead of the character skin. and this is my personal opinion, but half of the legendary skins arent even that much better than epic skins, all they have is the possibility to spend more to "customize" them a.k.a slight changes and different colors, you'd think they would put more effort into making the legendary skins, but apparently its not the case for every character
-despite being EXPENSIVE and a lot of people actually spending money for the chance of getting skins, myself included, it REALLY doesnt feel like they are putting ANYTHING back into making the game better. from my understanding, all they do is have the servers opened and they just copy the chinese game calabiyau and translate it, so literally any feedback you will have might never even have the possibility to reach the actual devs of the game
-event rewards are extremely lacking, the CN version of the game is much much better and we global players are treated as cows only to be milked, it really feels like theres no future for this game in the global space. all content creators and pros also left it if Im correct, but that is only natural when theres no tournaments or anything like that with real $ rewards. all you can get is like once in a few months a tournament that gives the equivalent of a few hundreds of dollars of in-game currency
-menus, UI, events, etc are really bad for a live service game that released 1 year ago. to this day you dont even have a "claim all" button for your inbox rewards. do we really need to get to the point where we have to ask for something so basic and obvious?

Lastly, I want to describe my experience of revisiting the game after +/- half an year later. Last I played was the beginning of season 3 and now it is season 6.
The changes I noticed:

1. The shop has like 10 times more pages for crap to buy for every possible spender (low spender, dolphin, whale, etc) 
Before you HAD TO BE a whale to consistently get the limited banner legendary character skins. F2p would have taken you FOREVER unless you got really lucky, since theres absolutely no daily rewards and most events that last WEEKS give like 1-3 pulls (pity is 80 pulls and you get either the character skin or the weapon skin and I think everyone agrees that the character skin is the only thing they want)
2. They added more half baked crap gamemodes, it feels like Im playing roblox or some modded minecraft modes. This isnt necessarily something bad, but remember how I said the low playerbase amount is a huge issue? Imagine splitting your already low playersbase across even more gamemodes. This has to be one of the worst decisions I've ever seen. When I came back yesterday I waited literally for 1 hour trying to find a match on Escort gamemode and I gave up because it wasnt finding anything(the estimated time told me it will take 1:55 minutes btw, straight up lying in my face)
3. One good thing I saw was they added some sort of reputation system, so from my understanding if the AI detects you said certain words or other people report you, you lose reputation, and then you cant queue in ranked or even use text chat or VC anymore. This sounds good on paper, but since I couldnt play the game because I was waiting forever to queue, I dont know much besides that, so I have no clue if its well implemented or not.
4. Very few balance changes (I went to training room and had a quick look at the characters and I noticed very few changed) some of them were good and some of them were good but also not. for example this 1 character Lawine in the past could throw a knife that just scans a pretty large area and pretty much gives wallhacks. Paired with smoking abilities or grenades it was OP. So Im assuming they wanted to nerf that synergy, so now she has 2 knives instead of 1 but it lasts way shorter and activates much faster. So now shes just a map info spamming demon. The enemy team will get very frequent updates on your locations if you are or not somewhere which just imagining about it feels very annoying.

Strinova is a generic third person pvp shooter with character unlocking like a MOBA, loadout customization like COD or Battlefield, visuals like Valorant, gamemodes like in Overwatch or CS2, and ultimately plays like a Roblox game.

There is nothing substantial that really distinguishes the game from others. [list][*]Most of their content releases are just expensive new skins for characters, weapons, profile cosmetics, etc. Some skins even offer p2w advantages like superior sights.
[*]Matchmaking often puts good players into a team of newbies who are less helpful than easy-difficulty bots against pre-made stacks (players in a team queuing together).
[*]They often make sneaky moves like changing your selected game mode to 'Outbreak', a failed game mode that they are proud of developing.
[*]Toxic players do not receive punishment, because they are big spenders or because the population of players is continually dwindling. 
[*]The game's ranked system has also fallen to the point to where the top positions are activity-based rather than measuring skill.[/list]

As of now, I reached 500 hours in Strinova (Switched to client launcher earlier this season). And genuinely, I love this game. It's amazing. The gunplay is fun, the mechanics are great, and I genuinely don't get bored of it.

[h3] Nothing [/h3]
Sadly. This season has been a rollercoaster of nothing. Each time I think the developpers are making a step in the right decision (a.k.a. FINALLY listening to our feedbacks even if it was only for two weeks), they make another that comes to slap me right back in the face, like keeping the matchmaking in the horrendous state it is in. It's not fair, fun, and doesn't give us any reason to play past getting the event rewards and completing the battle pass.

[h3] Game modes [/h3]
In terms of game modes, Strinova has been struggling. This season was the removal of Crystal Scramble on the chinese servers, which was a perfectly fine game mode that also got gatekept from the global playerbase despite us asking for it. Since season 3's second update, they've also been releasing alot of poorly designed game modes that have no real content and are just scrapped as fast as they get released. Conquest was a wasted potential, Boom Fest was just sad, Bobblehead Brawl was just a "headshot" TDM... so on. Only modes that made some sense are Outbreak, which the vast majority of global player hates due to p2w mechanics and just the mode not being fair for most, and Map Workshop, which is a great feature, but that there's no possibility for global players to enjoy since our community isn't growing to support such a mode.

[h3] Cosmetics [/h3]
I don't think it's the most important part, but I feel like it's important for me to say that skins in this game are absolutely not worth it. They cost more than the average shooter and half of them are locked behind a gacha that's definitely not consumer friendly with epic pity that resets when you roll a legendary or no actual way to guarantee getting every item on a banner without pulling more than the amount needed to get the legendary skin and the gun. I do think being able to get free legendary skins every once in a while f2p is good. But it's hard and the developpers haven't been the most generous in terms of rewards with this season's events, making it a pain for people who missed out on s4's events.

[h3] Visibility [/h3]
The studio behind the game has been doing nothing to help the playerbase grow back. They werent present at GameScom unlike games like Fate Trigger and Arknight: Endfield. There hasn't been any form of advertisement after the second week of release and genuinely, the only new players we get are people stumbling upon it randomly on X and YouTube. That's not how you promote a game.

[h3] Future of the game [/h3]
With season 5 being not that great, you'd expect season 6 to remedy to those things. But with no Test Servers in China and our only real information being a scythe shown in a 10 seconds clip, the upcoming season is looking very grim and I'm scared that Strinova might just not recover if we go down the current planned path for 2026 (PvE mode, Rework of the dorm system when global has yet to get the 9 dorms, no Demolition map for the rest of 2025). Season 5 was filler, but Strinova can't afford many seasons like that in a row unless they want to end up like Fall Guys, which has not gotten meaningful content in so many seasons.

[h3] So what? [/h3]
If you're a new player looking for a shooter with depth and mechanics just to kill time, I'd tell you to play Strinova and that it's cool. I'd really do. But it'd be a lie. Because Strinova is hanging on threads and the developpers seem too hyperfixated on their upcoming mobile version to think about the global playerbase and the version of the game that's available right now.

Hopefully this game recovers. But for now it's not.

Played it from release until the start of season 3 when I stopped, so here's my thoughts.

Good:
-paper mechanic, although looks goofy, it actually feels fresh and even good as you learn to use it for movement
-gameplay is actually really smooth which I didnt expect from an anime looking game that I never heard about before (I found it on the daily steam discovery queue)

-gameplay actually has depth and you can do a lot of things that will help you improve, other than just having good aim

Bad:
-low playerbase which results in many other issues like long waiting time for matchmaking and unbalanced matchmaking and such, making players in ranked be sick and tired and more likely to be toxic, or they stop playing ranked and they flood the casual matches, so you cant even catch a break even if you are trying to play something casual and relax
-unbalanced characters. even at base, some characters are always better than others, but when you take into account map control and specific strategies and synergies, the right character makes a difference of heaven or hell

-event rewards are extremely lacking, the CN version of the game is much much better and we global players are treated as cows only to be milked, it really feels like theres no future for this game in the global space. all content creators and pros also left it if Im correct, but that is only natural when theres no tournaments or anything like that with real $ rewards. all you can get is like once in a few months a tournament that gives the equivalent of a few hundreds of dollars of in-game currency
-menus, UI, events, etc are really bad for a live service game that released 1 year ago. to this day you dont even have a "claim all" button for your inbox rewards. do we really need to get to the point where we have to ask for something so basic and obvious?
-when I played, estimated time for matchmaking always said around 2 minutes, but it could easily reach even 1 hour and on top of that the matchmaking is really REALLY loose, when I was an average joe and ended up in a team of average people, the enemy team had the top1 EU server player at the time and other high ranks. when this happened, I started paying more attention to the names of everyone and noticed I was matched up with players of top300 on a daily basis multiple times, while I was silver or gold, which is like 5 or 6 ranks below them, iirc

I could say more things, but these were the main issues that came to mind.
Lastly, I want to describe my experience of revisiting the game after +/- half an year later. Last I played was the beginning of season 3 and now it is season 6.
The changes I noticed:

1. The shop has like 10 times more pages for crap to buy for every possible spender (low spender, dolphin, whale, etc)

Ok. So. The game was fun in the first 3 seasons. Lively community, fun no matter the elo, and the feeling of having that cool looking skin on your favorite character. 

Now the game is dead, and you're stuck winning ranked games against bots with scores like 9 to 0. The game feels like an eerie gmod map with echoes of its past. 

They won't do anything to bring back the playerbase, and yet are still incredibly greedy for a game at the end of its life.

While I want more and more players to come so that the game can be enjoyable again and can say it is worth trying to any new player interested, I won't hide the truth of how dead and greedy the game is.

This game has such a big potential to become a great game, BUT, the game devs are more lazy than mitsubishi making cars (evos to mid suv is crazy work lmfao). They put more time into making skins than rather focus on community feedback and gameplay itself. Adding on top of that, most servers (including ranked) are most of time (85-95% of the time) fully filled with bots so you're basically fighting pve in a pvp game which gets boring REAL quick. I love this game, I truly do, but theres too much cons than pros that weighs this game down real badly.

Pros: 
another hero shooter, but with anime girls and a few guys
neat special skills tied to each character
unique movements and maneuverability. 

Cons:
HEAVILY monetized, with gacha elements that is on par with the FATE mobile game. 
Games are heavily botted with little to no actual players with a dead global chat \
Every month, there is a new set to buy from, but each set is like, 4000+ yen for a single skin or gamba
gameplay has various modes, but since this is not a very active game, you usually get the most broken bots that will run to a wall rather than shoot the enemy, or miss 95% of shots. 

Overall; I guess it's like a novelty with some players, but it does not feel very good playing this game and gets incredibly boring very quickly.
